subtitle: [Music]
i'm steve nash i'm a curator of
archaeology here at the denver museum of
nature and science
and i want to thank you for joining us
for another tiny lecture installment of
the archaeology now
series i'm in the avenir collection
center where we have priceless
archaeological artifacts from all over
the world
i want to spend some time with you today
talking about ancient sandals
not because i like shoes necessarily but
because i love the fact that many caves
in the american west are full of ancient
sandals
and this is a question that we really
don't have a good answer for but we have
some good ideas
in my hand is a wonderfully complex
sandal it's a shoe
from the big bend area of texas and it's
made of yucca fiber as you can see
but it's also got strands of different
gauge um
uh weaving a different gauge rope that
people have put together for the the toe
holds and for the ties that go around
the ankle and so on
it's an amazingly complex piece of
technology
also from that part of the world we have
a couple of leather moccasins
right these aren't moccasins in the type
that we would um think of in colder
climates where the moccasin might come
up over the ankle bone
but these are clearly leather and so
basically they're leather sandals with
different ties
and then finally the group in front of
me over here are some sandals
from arizona and new mexico where i
actually do archeological field work now
so why are caves full of sandals i think
what we should do is think about the
clothing that people were wearing
they would have been wearing leather
clothes they would have been wearing
some cotton textiles
and so on but what's the most durable
piece of clothing that they would have
it's probably on their
feet but that doesn't explain the
disproportionately high
number of sandals that we find in caves
so i spoke with a colleague octavius
sayotoa who's leader of the zuni
cultural resources assessment team
about the high number of sandals that
were found in tularosa cave in west
central new mexico
and he thinks that sandals are found in
such large proportions in caves
because sandals are the connection
between the individual and mother earth
and caves themselves our connection
between the surface of the earth
and the underworld if you will and it's
a good
idea as any that i've heard for why
there's so many sandals in
caves but we would like you to keep
pondering this question as you think
about your own feet
your own footwear and how we ascribe
meaning
to those artifacts because i think it's
clear that people in the past described
a lot of meaning
to the footwear that they enjoy thank
you so much
and come back again for another
installment of archaeology now
